issue.title: SIKE not properly disabled on unsupported architectures
issue.body: With Debian now trying to [package liboqs](https://tracker.debian.org/pkg/liboqs), they build on a lot more platforms than we support, many of which [the build fails on](https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=liboqs).  I'm not suggesting we try to support those at this point in time.  However, one set of build failures (see e.g. [this build log](https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=liboqs&arch=mips64el&ver=0.7.0.27.gba5b61a7%2Bdfsg-1&stamp=1637141544&raw=0)) seems to be related to SIKE's config.h header file thinking it's on an unsupported architecture, but apparently CMake still tried to compile SIKE.  In other words, there seems to be a mismatch between architectures where CMake thinks it should try compiling SIKE and architectures that SIKE's config.h header file is willing to support.

comment.body:
> there seems to be a mismatch between architectures where CMake thinks it should try compiling SIKE and architectures that SIKE's config.h header file is willing to support

I'm not sure this is the case: There [already is a guard](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/8df1a81dd7e01901456f8666456b107cb2ab972d/CMakeLists.txt#L68-L72) explicitly overruled in this build.

> I can add a compile guard in the CMakeLists building on non-supported platform. 

Given the pre-existing guard, what about just adding a SIKE-disablement instruction into that guard (and maybe for all other algorithms we know fail building on something unknown)?

> Do we have an environment to test this?

I'm not aware we have a test or cross-dev environment for MIPS.

issue.title: CR+LF line endings in some of files
issue.body: I have noticed that `appveyor.yml` and `src/kem/sike/external/P751/AMD64/fp_x64_asm.S` have CR+LF (`\r\n`) line endings. While this is a very minute issue, some of tools employed in Debian packaging have minor problems with it (I should probably find a way to deal with them too). But if there is no difference, maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project? If this could not be done for `appveyor.yml` due to usage in Windows, maybe then line endings could be unified throughout all `*asm.S` files?

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
> Yes!! Very realistic!

Thanks for that confirmation. Could you then please help fill my "wireshark knowledge holes" as per the below?

> From what I remember stock, wireshark should recognize the traffic as TLS but not understand any of the groups nor signature schemes. So, maybe something else has gone wrong?

It looks like this: A plain vanilla wireshark running with the filter "ip.addr == 149.81.106.123" does not recognize TLS traffic when observing curl (successfully) connecting to our OQS-test server: `docker run -it openquantumsafe/curl sh -c "curl -k https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6007 --curves kyber512"` but shows this:
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/142979173-1bbfdfb3-e473-4d5f-8a15-d49edde8ae8c.png)

Looks like it considers this X11 traffic... What am I doing wrong?

> Another minor point is that you specify frodo640aes but please note that the patch does not allow for recognition of that particular codepoint. Only SABER, KYBER, NTRU and their hybrids codepoints are recognized. Of course, if you would like to add it, please feel free to do so.

Agreed, so see above: This is contacting a "Kyber-enabled" port (6007) which I think the patched wireshark should work with, right?

> Perhaps it would be more appropriate if this was done more like chromium and just built without docker? [...] Please let me know your opinion on this matter.

Agreed again: I'm all for taking small steps: 
1) Probably should be a shell script building a working `wireshark` on an Ubuntu x64
2) Adding the patch then
3) Running this against the test server with an algorithm readily supported by the patch demoing the scenario described above
4) Adding all other OQS algorithms thus creating a wireshark working for both wolfssl and oqs-openssl
5) Moving (and testing) the build to Alpine (but maybe only later -- this is just to save size)
6) Moving it into a docker image

--> What'd you say, @anhu: Reasonable? Any steps you could contribute (without going against your business commitments)? With a bit of help around understanding wireshark I think I may also take them on if that'd ease things.

issue.title: CR+LF line endings in some of files
issue.body: I have noticed that `appveyor.yml` and `src/kem/sike/external/P751/AMD64/fp_x64_asm.S` have CR+LF (`\r\n`) line endings. While this is a very minute issue, some of tools employed in Debian packaging have minor problems with it (I should probably find a way to deal with them too). But if there is no difference, maybe the same newline convention could be used throughout the project? If this could not be done for `appveyor.yml` due to usage in Windows, maybe then line endings could be unified throughout all `*asm.S` files?

comment.body:
> I would prefer all the files required to build liboqs on Linux-type systems to have LF line endings.

Thanks for the clear statement. We currently have this state but I'll add another PR to protect against regression to this state.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body: @anhu: Please check out [this script](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/blob/mb-wireshark/wireshark/build.sh) as a first cut implementing items 1-4 above (supporting all OQS, incl. hybrid, algorithm IDs). The resultant `wireshark` executable runs locally with the same issues as described above for a "standard-issue"/apt-installed `wireshark`: It doesn't properly recognize/dissect TLS traffic directed towards the OQS-TLS interop server (but still thinks this is X11 traffic). Suggestions regarding that problem (but also for improvement) _very_ welcome.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
OK, works like a charm now, even for hybrid algorithms: 
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57787676/143041368-78b57632-46bb-4159-bdb9-96cd165ba4e3.png)

I'll now try to "dockerize" this so you can try the image with a wolfssl install, @anhu.

As for the demo I'm not sure whether we should make this self-contained (also containing QSC-TLS server, say apache, and client, say curl, alongside wireshark or just `wireshark`... Opinions? @dstebila ?

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body: Wow....lots of progress!!  Sorry I haven't  been able to reply to your messages.  I'm in the North American Eastern time zone. :)

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
>  I'm in the North American Eastern time zone.

Ah, OK -- sorry, for whichever reason I thought you're based in France.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
Nice progress Michael!

> As for the demo I'm not sure whether we should make this self-contained (also containing QSC-TLS server, say apache, and client, say curl, alongside wireshark or just `wireshark`... Opinions? @dstebila ?

Is it easy for a Docker-ized wireshark to be able to capture transmissions between things outside of its container?  If someone has to successfully orchestrate three containers (wireshark, Apache, curl) to be able to run this, that's pretty rough.  In which case I'd be inclined to throw Apache and curl in there, so that they have something that they can more easily start using.

issue.title: Add wireshark with wolfSSL's names for OIDs and codepoints.

comment.body:
> Ah, OK -- sorry, for whichever reason I thought you're based in France.

Hahaha.... I wish I was in France right now.  I'm actually in the same city as @dstebila ; Waterloo, Ontario, Canada. And I agree with him, great progress!

issue.title: Adding arm64_v8 optimized versions of saber.
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
This PR adds arm optimized versions of lightsaber, firesaber, and saber from PQClean.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
This PR resolves: #1122, but looks like there is an issue with upstream where the frame pointer gets corrupted. (PQCLEAN: issue [#431](https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/issues/431#issue-1059280939))
<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming?  (If so, PRs in OQS-OpenSSL, OQS-BoringSSL, and OQS-OpenSSH will also be required by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: This is pending a fix to upstream. Not sure on the time frame yet.
